abstracts.cdata!:
Two key objectives of the Forestry and
            Conservation Project for Papua New guinea are to a)
            strengthen the capacity of local people, government, and
            nongovernmental entities to more sustainably manage and
            conserve the country's resources; and b) improve the
            quality of life of people living at the local level. The
            project has four main components. The first develops and
            implements a process whereby landowners will become more
            aware of options in using their forests. Its three
            sub-components comprise consultative activities to improve
            landowner access to information and discussions of
            development options prior to any land-use decisions;
            improved processes and systems for landowner representation
            and organization to allow improved resource decisionmaking
            will be developed and implemented; and policy and
            legislative development. The second component establishes a
            Conservation Trust Fund with GEF support, and develops a
            co-financing strategy. The third component augments the
            efforts of the forest authority and other institutions
            involved in sustainable management of the country's
            forests. It improves capacity specifically by improving
            forest operations, inspection, and monitoring; forest
            management planning; and expanding activities that maintain
            forest production as well as ecological potential. The
            fourth component provides technical assistance for
            environmental assessment and monitoring while building
            apacity within the Office of Environment and Conservation.
